title: Poisson frequency analysis of a French MTPL dataset
text: analysis, explore relationship response variable ClaimNb explanatory variables DriverAge Density. modeling framework aligns principles outlined Agresti (2013), prominent figure statistical methodology, emphasizes significance considering multiple explanatory factors regression analysis. relationship study can represented following equation: \[ \begin{equation} \text{ClaimNb} \sim \text{Poisson}(\lambda) \end{equation} \] \[ \begin{equation} \log(\lambda) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \times \text{DriverAge} + \beta_2 \times \text{Density} \end{equation} \] estimated lambda parameter mean claims : 0.05. theoretical empirical histograms associated Poisson distribution sown (fig-plot-hist-claims?). Theoretical empirical histogram claims frequence Coefficients Count-Ratio Confidence intervals count ratio represents change count making claim associated one-unit increase predictor variable, compared reference category DriverAge (18,22]. example, count ratio 0.68 DriverAge (22,26] implies count making claim individuals aged 22 26 approximately 32% lower compared reference category. Similarly, count ratios 1 Density categories suggest increase count making claim density increases within category.
code: set.seed(1234)   theoretic_count <- rpois(nrow(CONTRACTS.f), mean(CONTRACTS.f$ClaimNb))  tc_df <- tibble(theoretic_count)  freq_theoretic <- prop.table(table(tc_df$theoretic_count))  freq_claim <- prop.table(table(CONTRACTS.f$ClaimNb))  freq_theoretic_df <- tibble(    Count = as.numeric(names(freq_theoretic)),   Frequency = as.numeric(freq_theoretic),   Source = "Theoretical Count" )  freq_claim_df <- tibble(   Count = as.numeric(names(freq_claim)),   Frequency = as.numeric(freq_claim),   Source = "Empirical Count" )  freq_combined <- freq_theoretic_df |>    rbind(freq_claim_df) ggplot(freq_combined, aes(x = Count, y = Frequency, fill = Source)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge2", width = 0.3) +   labs(x = "Claim Number", y = "Frequency", fill = "Legend") +   theme(legend.position = "right") +   scale_fill_manual(     NULL,     values = c("Empirical Count" = "black", "Theoretical Count" = "#1E88E5")   ) +   labs(fill = "Legend") +   labs(x = "Claim Number", y = NULL) +   theme(legend.position = "right")+   global_theme() reg_coef <- tidy(reg)  reg_coef$p.value <- format(reg_coef$p.value, scientific = TRUE, digits = 3)  kable(reg_coef) kable(exp(coef(reg)[-1])) kable(exp(confint(reg))[-1, ]) ## Waiting for profiling to be done...

text: Poisson regression model predicting ClaimNb (number claims) DriverAge Density predictors. coefficients indicate change log count claims associated predictor level compared reference level. instance, DriverAge increases 22 26, log count claims decreases 0.39 Similarly, Density increases within category, log count claims increases. coefficients statistically significant.

Error z value Pr(>|z|)     ## (Intercept)           -2.5436     0.0843  -30.16  < 2e-16 *** ## DriverAge(22,26]      -0.3902     0.1009   -3.87  0.00011 *** ## DriverAge(26,42]      -0.7148     0.0819   -8.73  < 2e-16 *** ## DriverAge(42,74]      -0.7152     0.0807   -8.87  < 2e-16 *** ## DriverAge(74,Inf]     -0.6946     0.0924   -7.52  5.5e-14 *** ## Density(40,200]        0.1721     0.0377    4.57  4.9e-06 *** ## Density(200,500]       0.2965     0.0421    7.04  1.9e-12 *** ## Density(500,4.5e+03]   0.4935     0.0375   13.15  < 2e-16 *** ## Density(4.5e+03,Inf]   0.6987     0.0583   11.98  < 2e-16 *** ## --- ## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ##  ## (Dispersion parameter for poisson family taken to be 1) ##  ##     Null deviance: 42434  on 135106  degrees of freedom ## Residual deviance: 42071  on 135098  degrees of freedom ## AIC: 55722 ##  ## Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 6 dispersiontest(reg) ##  ##  Overdispersion test ##  ## data:  reg ## z = 7, p-value = 5e-12 ## alternative hypothesis: true dispersion is greater than 1 ## sample estimates: ## dispersion  ##          1

code: count_ratio <- exp(coef(reg)[-1]) conf_int <- exp(confint(reg))[-1, ]  driver_age_vars <- grep("^DriverAge", names(count_ratio), value = TRUE)  data_age <- tibble(   variable = driver_age_vars,   coefficient = count_ratio[driver_age_vars],    lower_bound = conf_int[driver_age_vars, 1],    upper_bound = conf_int[driver_age_vars, 2] )   driver_density_vars <- grep("^Density", names(count_ratio), value = TRUE)  data_density <- tibble(   variable = driver_density_vars,   coefficient = count_ratio[driver_density_vars],    lower_bound = conf_int[driver_density_vars, 1],    upper_bound = conf_int[driver_density_vars, 2] )  ggplot(   data_age |>   mutate(variable = fct_rev(variable)),    aes(     x = coefficient,     y = variable,     xmin = lower_bound,     xmax = upper_bound   ) ) +   geom_point(stat = "identity", size = 3, color = "#1E88E5") +   geom_errorbar(     width = 0.2,     position = position_dodge(width = 0.6),     color = "#1E88E5"   ) +   labs(     x = NULL,     y = NULL   ) +   global_theme() data_density <- data_density |>    mutate(variable = reorder(variable, coefficient, decreasing = TRUE))  ggplot(   data_density,    aes(     x = coefficient,     y = variable,     xmin = lower_bound,     xmax = upper_bound   ) ) +   geom_point(     stat = "identity",     size = 3,     color = "#1E88E5"   ) +   geom_errorbar(     width = 0.2,     position = position_dodge(width = 0.6),     color = "#1E88E5"   ) +   labs(     x = NULL,     y = NULL   ) +   global_theme()

title: QuasiPoisson frequency analysis of a French MTPL dataset
text: results QuasiPoisson regression models valid : responses independent. responses distributed according Poisson distribution parameter Lambda. analysis, explore relationship response variable ClaimNb explanatory variables DriverAge Density. modeling framework aligns principles outlined Agresti (2013), prominent figure statistical methodology, emphasizes significance considering multiple explanatory factors regression analysis. relationship study can represented following equation: \[ \begin{equation} \text{ClaimNb} \sim \text{QuasiPoisson}(e^{X\beta + \log E}) \end{equation} \] \[ \begin{equation} \log(\lambda) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \times \text{DriverAge} + \beta_2 \times \text{Density} + \text{log(Exposure)} \end{equation} \] estimated lambda parameter mean claims : 0.05. theoretical empirical histograms associated Poisson distribution sown (fig-plot-hist-claims?). Theoretical empirical histogram claims frequence Quasi-Poisson regression model predicting ClaimNb (number claims) DriverAge Density predictors. coefficients indicate change log count claims associated predictor level compared reference level. instance, DriverAge increases 22 26, log count claims decreases 0.39 Similarly, Density increases within category, log count claims increases. coefficients statistically significant. Coefficients Count-Ratio Confidence intervals count ratio represents change count making claim associated one-unit increase predictor variable, compared reference category DriverAge (18,22]. example, count ratio 0.67 DriverAge (22,26] implies count making claim individuals aged 22 26 approximately 33% lower compared reference category. Similarly, count ratios 1 Density categories suggest increase count making claim density increases within category.
code: set.seed(1234)   theoretic_count <- rpois(nrow(CONTRACTS.f), mean(CONTRACTS.f$ClaimNb))  tc_df <- tibble(theoretic_count)  freq_theoretic <- prop.table(table(tc_df$theoretic_count))  freq_claim <- prop.table(table(CONTRACTS.f$ClaimNb))  freq_theoretic_df <- tibble(    Count = as.numeric(names(freq_theoretic)),   Frequency = as.numeric(freq_theoretic),   Source = "Theoretical Count" )  freq_claim_df <- tibble(   Count = as.numeric(names(freq_claim)),   Frequency = as.numeric(freq_claim),   Source = "Empirical Count" )  freq_combined <- freq_theoretic_df |>    rbind(freq_claim_df) ggplot(freq_combined, aes(x = Count, y = Frequency, fill = Source)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge2", width = 0.3) +   labs(x = "Claim Number", y = "Frequency", fill = "Legend") +   theme(legend.position = "right") +   scale_fill_manual(     NULL,     values = c("Empirical Count" = "black", "Theoretical Count" = "#1E88E5")   ) +   labs(fill = "Legend") +   labs(x = "Claim Number", y = NULL) +   theme(legend.position = "right")+   global_theme() freg <- formula(ClaimNb ~ DriverAge + Density + offset(log(Exposure)))    reg <- glm(freg, family = quasipoisson, data = CONTRACTS.f)  summary(reg) ##  ## Call: ## glm(formula = freg, family = quasipoisson, data = CONTRACTS.f) ##  ## Coefficients: ##                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     ## (Intercept)           -2.5317     0.0858  -29.52  < 2e-16 *** ## DriverAge(22,26]      -0.3938     0.1026   -3.84  0.00012 *** ## DriverAge(26,42]      -0.7219     0.0833   -8.66  < 2e-16 *** ## DriverAge(42,74]      -0.7235     0.0820   -8.82  < 2e-16 *** ## DriverAge(74,Inf]     -0.7053     0.0939   -7.51  6.1e-14 *** ## Density(40,200]        0.1726     0.0383    4.50  6.7e-06 *** ## Density(200,500]       0.2972     0.0428    6.94  3.9e-12 *** ## Density(500,4.5e+03]   0.4949     0.0382   12.96  < 2e-16 *** ## Density(4.5e+03,Inf]   0.7049     0.0593   11.88  < 2e-16 *** ## --- ## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ##  ## (Dispersion parameter for quasipoisson family taken to be 1) ##  ##     Null deviance: 42457  on 135106  degrees of freedom ## Residual deviance: 42089  on 135098  degrees of freedom ## AIC: NA ##  ## Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 6 reg_coef <- tidy(reg)  reg_coef$p.value <- format(reg_coef$p.value, scientific = TRUE, digits = 3)  kable(reg_coef) kable(exp(coef(reg)[-1])) kable(exp(confint(reg))[-1, ]) ## Waiting for profiling to be done...

title: Property and casualty insurance demand — PnCdemand
Property and casualty insurance demand — PnCdemand
text: PnCdemand contains 22 columns: "Name" character country name. "Country" numeric country identifier. "Time" numeric time identifier. "GNPCAP" numeric Gross national product,         US dollars per capita.. "NewMEAS" numeric new measure wealth produced World Bank.     composite measure includes human resources, produced manufactured assets natural resources.     variable time-invariant. wealth per capita, thousands US dollars. "RiskAversion" numeric risk aversion, proxied level education.     measured enrollment ratio third-level education, , ratio total enrollment     third-level education institutions total population age 20 24. Education third level     provided different types institutions, including universities, teacher-training institutions technical institutes. "Protect" numeric protective measures may reduce competition thus raise prices.     Trade barriers proxied insurance market share foreign firms. Specifically, market     share branches agencies foreign undertakings total domestic non-life insurance. "PopDens" numeric population density, average number people living within square kilometer. "Urban" numeric urbanization. percentage people living urban areas. "LegalSyst" numeric legal system. indicator variable equal     one country common law system zero otherwise (statutory law system). variable time-invariant. "CPI" numeric Consumer Price Index, percentage. "Auto" Automobile premium density, computed total direct gross automobile insurance premiums     divided country's population. includes damage loss land vehicles well liability arising     use motor vehicles. measure US dollars per capita. "Transport" Transport premium density. Transport insurance includes railway loss, aircraft     loss liability ship loss liability. "Freight" Freight premium density. includes damage loss goods transit baggage. "FireProp" Fire property damage premium density. includes damage loss     property due fire, explosion, storm, natural forces, nuclear energy land subsidence well damage property. "PecLoss" Pecuniary loss premium density. includes credit loss, surety loss miscellaneous financial losses. "GenLiab" General liability premium density. includes liability motor vehicle, aircraft ship liability. "AccSick" Accident sickness premium density. "OtherNL" non-life premium density. includes legal expenses, assistance miscellaneous insurance. "MRATE" Motor vehicle ownership per capita. "NumAcc" ? "Population" Total population number.

what: Large commercial risks in Asia-Pacific — asiacomrisk
title: Large commercial risks in Asia-Pacific — asiacomrisk
text: completed project Insurance Risk Finance Research Centre (www.IRFRC.com) assembled unique dataset Large Commercial Risk losses Asia-Pacific (APAC) covering period 2000-2013. data generously contributed one global reinsurance company two large Lloyd's syndicates London. dataset result project co-lead Dr Milidonis (IRFRC University Cyprus) Enrico Biffis (Imperial College Business School), can referred IRFRC LCR Dataset. expected, dataset fully anonymised, LCR losses aggregated along dimensions. First, data categorised based World Bank's economic development classification. means losses either come developed developing countries. second dimension used aggregate data time period covered. Data grouped (least) two time-periods: period 2008 crisis. large commercial risk (LCR) defined loss caused man-made risks (e.g. fire, explosion, etc.). exclude natural catastrophe events, started focusing claims made data provider incur loss amount least EUR 1 million. extended dataset include claims leading loss amounts smaller EUR 1 million. Given time constraints, partially extended loss data obtaining FGU losses larger EUR 140k. One note selection bias arising data collection exercise driven data quality reliability. Based experience, latter two attributes homogeneous across developed developing countries APAC claims. details, see technical report: Benedetti, Biffis Milidonis (2015a).

Usage character string type exposure hit loss:         "Commercial", "Energy", "Manufacturing",         "Misc.", "Residential". SubUsage character string precised type exposure hit loss:         "Commercial", "Energy", "General industry", "Metals/Mines/Chemicals",         "Misc.", "Residential", "Utility". DR numeric destruction rate (FGU divided TIV capped 1).

what: Brazilian geospatial dataset for municipalities — brgeomunicins
title: Brazilian geospatial dataset for municipalities — brgeomunicins
text: brgeomunic spatial database containing geospatial information Brazilian municipalities  provided IBGE, Brazilian governmental agency  charge geographical issues official statistics (ibge.gov.br, accessed February, 2013). brgeomunic geospatial dataframe class sp based three files:  one containing geographical coordinates polygons, lines dots (55mu2500gsd.shp);  another attribute data (55mu2500gsd.dbf); third file index  allows connection  .shp .dbf files(55mu2500gsd.shx).  brgeomunic provided two versions sp sf directory geodata github  directory, please visit repository https://github.com/dutangc/CASdatasets.  may also consider package geobr https://cran.r-project.org/package=geobr. final database restricted municipalities four Brazilian states  (Sao Paulo (SP), Santa Catarina (SC), Parana (PR), Rio Grande Sul (RS)).  states located southern region Brazil contain almost 70 million  inhabitants (around 36 percent Brazilian population) constitute one  richest regions country (approximately 60 percent Brazilian gross product). brgeomunicins dataframe insurance statistic information.   insurance information comes  one large actuarial  database provided SUSEP, agency responsible regulation supervision  Brazilian insurance, private pension, annuity, reinsurance markets.  SUSEP releases biannually car insurance database composed aggregation  insurance companies' information. Due confidentiality concerns,  individual-level information, data aggregated zip code areas.  Originally, SUSEP IBGE databases present unique identification column provides  forward merge two databases. joint information name state municipality. Insurance information selected compare premiums, claims, reported  damages two specific groups: popular vehicles luxury vehicles.  basic difference groups power engine  materials finishing quality.  Popular cars power 1,000 cc (cylinders), whereas luxury cars usually  power 2,000 cc greater.  Popular cars thus affordable customers. Pop group contains following selected popular vehicles: Celta 1.0 (Chevrolet), Corsa 1.0 (Chevrolet), Prisma 1.0  (Chevrolet), Uno 1.0 (Fiat), Palio 1.0 (Fiat), Gol 1. (Volkswagen), Fox 1.0  (Volkswagen), Fiesta 1.0 (Ford), Ka 1.0 (Ford). Lux group contains following selected luxury vehicles: Vectra (Chevrolet), Omega (Chevrolet),  Linea (Fiat), Bravo (Fiat), Passat (Volkswagen), Polo (Volkswagen), Fusion (Ford),  Focus (Ford), Corolla (Toyota), Civic (Honda), Audi. summary, brgeomunicins dataframe detailed information region, city code, yearly exposure, premium, frequency claims following categories: robbery theft (Rob), partial collision total loss (Coll), fire (Fire), others (). addition insurance statistics, final dataframe brgeomunicins also includes municipality population (CityDens10) based 2010 Census, 2000 municipality Human Development Index (HDIcity00).   Human Development Index (HDI) summary measure long-term progress three basic dimensions  human development: income, education, health. HDI provides counterpoint another widely   used indicator, Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita, considers economic dimensions. CityDens10 HDIcity00 columns generated IBGE site (ibge.gov.br, accessed February 2013).

title: French Disability Tables and Probabilities — freDisTables
text: Naming convention: X2Y stands going  state X state Y, possible states T (temporary disability),  P (permanent disability), D (death). instance, T2T stands temporary temporary disability. Tables freP2Pdis10, freT2Tdis10 freT2Pdis10 established French mutual (BCAC) mission mandated French association insurance companies (FFSA) imposed new retirement reglementation agreement professional federations. tables build 1993 extended age 62 2010 December 24 act 2010, cf. JO (2010). tables entirely rebuilt 2013 BCAC: new imposed tables Tables freP2Pdis13, freT2Tdis13  freT2Pdis13, see Bagui (2013). freP2Pdis10/freP2Pdis13 contain continuation table permanent disability (-called invalidity France) based 10,000-person reference population age 20 61 (resp. 20 64). freT2Tdis10/freT2Tdis13 contain continuation table temporary disability (-called incapacity France) based 10,000-person reference population age 20 66. (resp. 21 65). freT2Pdis10/freT2Pdis13 contain transition table (temporary permanent disability) based 10,000-person reference population age 20 61 (resp. 21 62). Note France temporary disability limited 36 months (irrespective entry age) permanent disability age capped age retirement 62 2010 tables (resp. 65 2013 tables). freT2Pdisprob10/freT2Pdisprob13, freT2Tdisprob10/freT2Tdisprob13,  freP2Pdisprob10/freP2Pdisprob13 corresponding probabilities deduced tables, respectively go temporary permanent disability, stay temporarily disabled stay permanently disabled, given entry age number month years already disabled. Tables freT2Ddis10, freP2Ddis10 established French mutual (BCAC) mission mandated French association insurance companies (FFSA) imposed new retirement reglementation agreement professional federations. freP2Ddis10 contains mortality table permanent disability (-called invalidity France) based 10,000-person reference population age 25 64. freT2Ddis10 contains mortality table temporary disability (-called incapacity France) based 10,000-person reference population age 25 65. freP2Ddisprob10, freT2Ddisprob10 corresponding probabilities deduced tables, respectively die temporary disability, die permanent disability, given entry age number month years already disabled.

title: Massachusetts Automobile bodily injury claim datasets — usmassBI

Potential fraudulent claims provider=. dataset usmassBI2 contains automobile bodily injury claims collected 1993 1998 Massachusetts, studied Frees Wang (2005). sample 29 Massachusetts towns described Frees (2003).
